comments.text:
You know what else is a huge oversight?  The number of children in the 
stretched-far-too-thin foster care program because whoops, there aren't a 
hundred people clamoring to adopt every unclaimed child in the U.S.  (can't 
say anything about other countries because I am not familiar with their 
systems.)

Adoption is a great solution to the abortion argument *in theory*.  No one 
has to worry about whether or not it counts as killing a person, and 
everyone gets to imagine a happy scenario where a previously barren couple 
gets to experience the feel good movie of raising a kid.  But in reality, 
the number of people who have the means to adopt AND want to is nowhere 
near enough to negate the number of abortions that end up being decided 
upon.  Plus, you also have to remember that taking care of the kid starts 
before the kid is born.  There are a lot of costs involved with most 
pregnancy, between doctor appointments (not to mention the delivery bill-- 
yikes), work conflicts, and general physical/social well-being.

comments.text:
+VenezuelanChic96

I know people are raised differently and that they form different opinions 
based upon that. Unfortunately, sometimes those upbringings lead to less 
open minds (not that I am implying this in your case. That's actually a 
statement on my own upbringing). My main goal, which I'm glad I was able to 
achieve, is to broaden horizons. I'm not telling you to change your entire 
view on everything (because that is a very difficult thing to do that comes 
with a lot of internal growth), but merely to look from perspectives 
outside your own, as well as your own, in order to form a more informed 
opinion.

As I said before, I was raised in a Christian family in the south 
(originally). Many members of my family still view homosexuality as a sin 
and sex as something to only be done between married couples. I used to 
share that closed-minded approach to people. But then I broadened my 
horizons and came to understand that making harsh judgements on people I 
don't know will get me nothing but negativity in my life. So I let go of 
the majority of those things that make me judge rashly, and I'm much 
happier for it. I see people for who they are, and not what they do (or who 
they do). I'm still in the process of that internal growth, and by no means 
an expert, and there are still some things that I struggle with. It's an 
ongoing process.

Wow I really got derailed from the topic there. lol

But anyway. I commend you for wanting to initiate some growth within 
yourself by learning from others. I don't think a youtube comment was the 
best way to go about it, simply because there are a lot of people who would 
rather argue than teach. I don't think it's pathetic of you to want to 
learn to broaden your views from other people, only that you may want to 
find a more opinion-safe place to do so.

I'm glad I could help in some of your growth, and best of luck to you in 
college.

I know you won't respond to this, but I would like to enlighten you.

First, you are in no position to judge anybody for having (or not having) 
sex. Now, the age of consent in most US states is 16, but people will 
experiment. Most bodies aren't ready for sex or babies until they are past 
middle school anyway, so your thing about 12-year-olds holds no place.

Second, you're right. Sex isn't everything. But having sex doesn't 
automatically mean you're going to have a baby. Especially if you take 
proper precautions (condoms and birth control come to mind). If given the 
option (and the proper information), people are more likely to choose to 
use protection so as to avoid unwanted pregnancies and STDs. Also, don't 
say "or worse abortion". Because abortion is not a fun decision to make, 
but you don't get to decide if someone is better or worse for having (or 
not having) one.

Nowhere in the video did it say that the Bible is fake. I was raised a 
Christian myself. My boyfriend was raised Catholic. We both had sex before 
we were twenty. We are both getting ready to graduate college; I'm 
graduating next year with a Major in Computer Science and a Minor in 
Mathematics. Sex doesn't ruin your life, especially if you have it out of 
wedlock. That's just a ridiculous standard set up by a religious 
organization that really doesn't get to have any say in what people do with 
their bodies.

And on the homosexuality thing. Again, comes from a ridiculous standard set 
up by a religious organization that really doesn't get to have any say in 
what people do with their bodies. If I had sex with a lady (as I am 
female), it would not affect you or your family in any way, shape, or form. 
It is not "immoral" and it certainly not something people "choose". 
Sexuality is part of a person's makeup and cannot be altered by other 
people.

So, if you please, get off your high horse and stop judging people. And as 
a final note, I would like to direct you to Luke 6:37 "Judge not, and you 
will not be judged; condemn not, and you will not be condemned; forgive, 
and you will be forgiven."

Have a nice day.

top_comment.text:
Question: Do you feel that prudence for teens is a good idea? Most of these 
laws are designed to protect teenagers and children from adults, not from 
each other. If a 12 year old has sex with another 12 year old, what is most 
potentially damaging; the sex it self, or the strain of going through court 
(in some countries) or the moral outrage to come?

And do you really think that teens who send nudes to eachother justifies 
convictions of production and/or obtaining or keeping child pornography? In 
my mind, this is simply disasterous... Children, and especially teens, are 
sexual being as much as we are but in a different way. By moralizing over 
it, we might end up causing harm when our intent is to shield.

Something to keep in mind, that's all.﻿

comments.text:
Haha, I'm 28 and married. But I honestly see no issue with children 
experimenting with their sexualities, no. Children playing doctor, or "I'll 
show mine if you show yours" is quite common place.

When grown ups creates hysteria about things that are so natural and 
healthy I am concerned about how this might affect our childrens mental 
health. Several studies have shown that children do indeed have sexual 
feelings and desires, yet they do not resemble the feelings and desires 
that grown ups do. However, their feelings do play a part in their 
development and thus my concern.

found in many different wild animals, for example:

if you want to put it that way.  Also, it's been scientifically proven not 
to be a mental illness since 1973. Here's more information about its

top_comment.text:
The term "bisexual" needs to be addressed; the term stems from an older 
perception of gender as being some binary thing where cisgenders were the 
only two genders considered to exist.

Pansexuality and omnisexuality are an expansion of this orientation to 
include relationships with trans*, asexual, demisexual, genderqueer and 
other orientations beyond relationships between cis-gender pairs.

And no, we are not confused, sick, greedy etc. In fact, you could do a 
whole segment just on bisexuality / pansexuality alone. And many have.﻿

comments.text:
Bisexuality still isn't that simple.  For example, I identify as bi, 
because I am attracted to men and women.  This can and does include trans* 
people, if they identify as male or female (for me, at least).  What this 
does mean, however, is that unlike pansexual people, I am not attracted to 
genderqueer, third-gender, or other-gendered people.

While I am sure some exist, I have personally never met a bisexual person 
who does not consider themselves attracted to trans* people identifying 
within the male/female boundaries, and as such this is a common 
misconception I would like cleared.

I would also like to clear the misconception that just because many of us 
identify as bi and not pan, it does not mean we don't believe 
other-gendered people exist.  I for one am very aware of their presence, I 
just happen to be attracted to people who identify within the male/female 
binary.
comments.author: SexBomb

comments.text:
I realise that and it could be seen just as insensitive to use any of those 
other names for the same reason.  And if this was used in any video that 
was purely humorous I wouldn’t have had a problem with it.  It is because 
it is used in a video that gives out a lot of factual information 
interlaced with humor which is where things get foggy, as the primary 
purpose of the video seems to be to inform using humor one should tread 
more carefully.
Whether this makes me a hypocrite or not, I don’t know.  But to me Tomska 
does overall two types of video (with various subsets) the Comic and the 
informative and making a distinction between these may come down to 
personal judgment there are distinction of what sort of humor is 
appropriate in each different case, which I will concede, can still be very 
subjective.
I appear to have waffled on but I hope I laid down my opinion in a non 
offensive manner, as this is not a personal attack on anyone just some 
rather drab criticism.
